People not knowing anything about this show might see the name and wonder, 'Is this show a porno or something?' And the simple answer is no. Doesn't even come close which is a good thing. 
Holic is a supernatural anime that follows our main lead Watanuki with an interesting ability to see spirits. Very much to his annoyance as he just wants to live a normal, peaceful life. One day while trying to escape from a spirit, he stumbles across a shop run by an odd woman called Yuko who specializes in the granting of wishes. She forces him to work for her as aform of payment for helping him to deal with his ability and so begins his new life as a part time worker in a less than normal environment. 


The story takes on a sort of episodic nature with some episodes dealing with various customers who stumble upon the shop while others deal with Watanuki dealing with various supernatural events so there isn't really a grand plot to the show. Despite this, it's very fun to watch and is quite comedic while some elements can get quite serious which I suppose makes it a sort of dark comedy. 


For our main characters we have of course Watanuki. He is an all round decent guy who enjoys sports and cooking and is extremely self-sufficient since his parents died at a young age. Since he was young, he's been able to see spirits to his utter dismay as they tend to be a nuisance rather than life threatening and sometimes makes him look like an escaped mental patient to people who happen to see him when he is being 'attacked'. He works part time at Yukos shop as an errand boy. He cooks and cleans for Yuko and is often sent out to shop for food and alcohol which annoys him most of the time. Then we have Yuko who is completely shrouded in mystery as we know very little about her or her past. She is generally very lazy, getting Watanuki to do everything for her and enjoys drinking a lot, usually suffering from hangovers the next day despite Watanuki's warnings. She often states that there is no such thing as coincidence, only inevitability which she often states to customers who don't understand why they came to the shop. She has a laid back sort of attitude to her work as she appears to get rather annoyed when someone shows up. She gives advice and objects to help them probably knowing he/she won't listen hence leaving the outcome to fate. Next we have Doumeki who is a 'friend' to Watanuki. They are in the same year in school. He comes from a family of monks and posses a power to repel spirits as a contrast of Watanuki's attraction of them. For this reason, Yuko always insists Watanuki have him by his side much to Watanukis annoyance. He acts as a rational thinker and calm, quiet personna to Watanuki's more eccentric and loud personality. One can say they compliment each other but Watanuki refuses to acknowledge it. He tends to find Watanuki annoying at times but still sees him as his best friend and is always there to help him no matter the risk. And finally we have Himawari, a classmate of Watanuki and obvious love interest for Watanuki who goes into a sort of 'lovey dovey' mood around her only to be 'interrupted' by Doumeki. She is generally upbeat and high spirited and loves seeing Watanuki and Doumeki together as she finds their actions together funny.     


The show has a few recurring characters such as an elder Fox who runs a food stand, a rain spirit who doesn't have much time for Watanuki or any human really and a more nicer spirit who seems to exhibit feelings for Watanuki but is very shy. We also have Maru and Moro. Yuko's 2 assistants. They seem to be young girls who speak in unison together and tend to play around a lot. And of course we have Mokona, a black Firby like creature that lives with Yuko. He often accompanies Watanuki on some jobs, usually just to boss him around and is Yuko's drinking buddy. 


Overall the shows characters are pretty well rounded and fun to watch. Watanuki's rage moments can get annoying at times but most are still quite funny so don't let it discourage. 


The show was made by Production I.G with the source material being a manga of the same name by CLAMP. The animation of the show is decent with it's best being during serious moments. However it can be quite inconsistent at times, especially when making legs and arms 10 feet long at times which isn't too much of an issue but still noticeable. The Japanese audio is pretty good with Jun Fukuyama as Watanuki who gives a great performance. The English audio is top notch to with Todd Haberkorn as Watanuki. One of my favourite Haberkorn performances. We also have Collen Clinkenbeard as Yuko and she gives a very performance, really nailing the mysterious nature of her character. J. Michael Tatum gives a nice performance of Doumeki. I believe he really nails silent nature of Doumeki very well. I believe Haberkorn and Tatum displayed great chemistry between their respective characters very well. Cherami Leigh gives a lovely performance as Himawari also. She highlights her outgoing personality well I think. I'd recommend to watch the show in English but if you're a sub person, the Japanese audio is perfectly fine to. 


I'd recommend this show as a buy personally. For folks, like myself, who live in the UK, you should be able to pick up the show pretty cheap from Manga UK. Funimation has the show licensed in the US and Madman has the show licensed in Australia. However the 2nd season remains unlicensed unfortunately. I hope it's gets picked up at some point.

xxxHolic (pronounced "holic") is an anime adaptation of a CLAMP manga of the same name. The anime was made as a 24-episode advertisement for the manga. There's no real overarching plot or even an end. The show expects you to read the manga if you want any kind of closure. This series is exactly what you'd expect from CLAMP. It's in each episode the main characters solve a person's problem, making the person happy by the end of the episode. If you've read anything by CLAMP you'll know what to expect. On top of that, the character designs for xxxHolic are downright ugly! Every characterlooks like some kind of demented Ent-frog with their tall, skinny bodies and long limbs. As much as I'm hating on it, it's not a terrible show. It's a lot like CLAMP's other non-Cardcaptor shows, remarkably average. So, if you've read the manga and want to see the exact same thing animated, then it might be worth checking out. But if you're not already in love with CLAMP, then you might want to skip this one.

xxxHolic is a 26-episode anime series produced by TBS and Production I.G. and is based on the CLAMP manga of the same name. It's a highly exciting and delightful anime, and will offer the viewer a different side of the CLAMP franchise. 
  The art of the anime is superlative. It takes time to get adjusted to the slightly unconventional art, but one soon gets used to it. Additionally, every character except the lead characters is not clearly drawn; rather, you get gray silhouettes which serve to further accentuate the lead characters’ behavior. 
  The lead characters themselves are very-well conceivedof. Their physical structure embodies their traits, and gives us a sense of something slightly off from the real world.\n
  That said the story is eerily un-CLAMP-like. There are not many happy endings, just enough to get the reader hooked. Most times, the evildoer gets a punishment for what he has done, in a way that serves to hold his crime up to the moral judgment of the viewer. But the damage is not restricted; sometimes, even the person who is nearby or a family member also gets mixed up. The story at times seems so real-life that one has to literally shake his illusions away. Several philosophical issues are treated with such deftness that even the hardiest Sophist would be hard put to deny their efficacy on the viewer’s mind.  \n
  The character conceptualization is a work of pure finesse, characteristic of I.G. works. Watanuki is a deep study in psychology, Yuuko Ichihara is one of the charismatic philosophers ever seen in anime, and both Domeki and Himawari depict two sides of the human animal: the strong, disbelieving side, and the believer inside every one of us. Maru and Moro, as well as the irritably cute Mokona, serve to lighten the viewer’s concentration with a dash of well-placed humor. Additional characters, such as the incredibly likable Vestal, and the hoity-toity Rain Sprite, also attract the viewer’s affection or irritation: an altogether natural reaction that all anime hopes for.\n
  The music for the show is great. The OP, Suga Shikao’s 19sai, is a foot-tapping number (and my flagship song, hee hee). Its tight vocals and awesome accompaniments will make it an effortless climber on your playlist for sure. The EDs are similarly awesome; the first one, Reason by Fonogenico, will bring out the goofy side of you, while the second ED, Kagerou by BUCK-TICK, is a great listen, well-assisted by the credit scene, where we see Maru and Moro playing air guitar. \n
  So, in conclusion, who do I recommend to? All the seriously concerned folks out there, for starters. Here many sensitive and basic ethical problems are treated with a delicacy and sophistry that’ll probably satisfy all your dreams of being philosophers. Secondly, all you guys who like the fables and myths of Japan should check it out; these abound in the anime. Thirdly, I’d recommend this anime to all those who enjoyed Ghost in the Shell and its beautiful leading lady; I assure you, Yuuko Ichihara is eminently suitable for your appreciation as well. \n
  But that’s of course just a suggestion. All are welcome to see this funny yet serious, hysterical yet humbling view of men and their conception of their true worth in the world.  \n

You'd think Watanuki would grow, learn, overcome and/oradapt but no (this becomes a problem considering how the last three episodes play out). While refreshing to see an anime stick with the same opening theme for 24 episodes, the two ending themes don't really fit the tone of the series. The gigantic bodies (or is it tiny heads?) that is the CLAMP signature is bothersome, but not annoying. It's distracting but not a distraction. It's worth pointing out because of a similar critique for Code Geass.\n

Heelllooo Anime community! It’s Cyn here, and I shall be reviewing xxxHOLiC! Please take care of me, as this will be my first review :3. So let’s rock!
Story: “Copied from xxxHOLiC Wiki”
Kimihiro Watanuki is a high school student plagued by yōkai and ayakashi spirits, both of which are invisible to everyone else but him. The series begins when Watanuki stumbles, seemingly by chance, into a shop that grants wishes. The shop is owned by Yūko Ichihara, a mysterious witch of many names and esoteric renown. For a price, she offers to grant Watanuki's wish to be rid of the spirits. The price, according to Yūko,must be of equal value; so, as payment, he must become Yūko's temporary, part-time cook and housekeeper. While his established job consists of household chores, Yūko increasingly sends him on errands of a supernatural or spiritual nature as the series develops. Himawari Kunogi, Watanuki's love interest, and Shizuka Dōmeki, a classmate whom Watanuki initially detests, occasionally join him in his work as per Yūko's request. The three become increasingly close, and though Watanuki is often annoyed with Dōmeki, he grows to value the new friendships he makes and his life at the wish shop.


My comment: So that is the gist of the first season, which is 23 episodes long [with a flash back-like extra] making it 24 episodes. There is also a movie, a live-action series, and a second season xxxHOLiC: Kei. The series is also a CLAMP series [I love CLAMP] which means it does intertwine with the Tsubasa Chronicles [which I have just started watching myself]. CLAMP is known for bringing us many anime/manga like Chobits, and a collaboration work that produced Code Geass. I will just be reviewing the first season…since I’m in the middle of the second season and just started the Tsubasa Chronicles, bear with me xD.


Characters: So there are about four characters that really stand out and that we get to see most often, and four that hold some importance to the series itself. Personally I liked the uniqueness of all the characters. I especially loved Mokona o_o…loved. An adorable chubby stuffed animal looking bunny, with some supernatural abilities; Mokona’s mouth was like a vacuum of sorts, sucking up evil auras, and such. Mokona also had the ability to see youkai, ayakashi spirits, and the dead. Not to mention Mokona is a heavy drinker like Yuuko. [More Sake! Pleeaaasee!]. Speaking of Yuuko, she is the owner of the wish shop. She holds some intense powers and is knowledgeable and all-seeing. She grants wishes by taking something of the collateral, but she’s also a heavy drinker [more like xxxALCOHOLiC] and an overbearing employer to our humble main character Watanuki. Now I can’t say I disliked Watanuki, he could cook, he could clean, he could see things we only dreamed of; and yet his character design flaw was his lack of concern for himself. He always thought of others before himself, well others…except for Doumeki. Kidding! He cared for Doumeki, somewhere deep inside. Doumeki was almost like a ‘love rival’ in his eyes although he was born as a natural spirit repeller. [Err…like insect repellent but…a human…]. Yuuko constantly pairs Doumeki and Watanuki together because as long as Doumeki is around, spirits won’t attack Watanuki. He’s athletic [Arching], and very nonchalant I could honestly say he was my favorite human character. Well, earlier I mentioned ‘love-rival’; enter Himawari-chaaaan. Watanuki’s love interest [he’s literally obsessed], but as Yuuko said herself, and I quote: “I don’t think she is your destined one”. Himawari is not the most annoying female character; she’s often helping Watanuki, hanging out with both him and Doumeki. She likes creepy things, and honestly gives off a vibe sometimes…something’s not right with her…I swear. Alright, now the secondary characters! Maru & Moro adorable as they are, they are soulless assistants that work in the shop. They speak in rhymes and patterns and are just, adorable. Yet, they cannot leave the shop because they lack real souls. Next, Zashiki-warashi, she’s a spirit girl, she’s adorable and shy, but has a crush on Watanuki. She cries often and has these karasutengu guarding her and they attack Watanuki whenever she cries…even if they are happy-happy tears…[poor guy]. Lastly there is Ame-warashi who is a rain spirit, and does not have the best opinion of humans. She’s like a big sister to Zashiki-warashi and cares for her well-being. There are maaannny other characters I don’t think hold that much significance in the first season so I shall not speak of them. 8/10


Art/Sound: You must be thinking. What lanky long bodies they have. That’s CLAMP’s style and at first, that’s what I thought too. It’s a part of the reason why I wasn’t too appealed to several CLAMP series [at first]…except Chobits. God, I loved Chobits. Although the art style may not look too appealing, Production I.G Studio does a good job with keeping the art style of the original. I love that, and it grows on you. They make their lanky people look gooood. If you’re not familiar with Suga Shikao. Search him, now. 19sai the opening song for xxxHOLiC fit perfectly. It kept the dark theme and mysteriousness of the series so real I loved it! Although I haven’t looked too much into their OSTs their soundtrack is nothing to laugh at, really. It’s amazing how nicely the show and the sound just fit together. 7/10


Overall: ‘Twas an awesome and beautiful series that got me hooked on it, and made me really look at CLAMP in a whole new light. Blew my mind, and almost every expectation I had for it. Would I recommend it? Most definitely, but if you’re not into mysterious, somewhat spine chilling things that make you take a second look at life. This probably isn’t the show for you, and that’s okey because I believe there is an anime out there for everyone no matter how different your tastes may be. This anime resonated with me. I give it an 8.5/10!

xxxHolic is the first anime that I had watched in a while. I wanted to get back into the Anime, and a friend suggested this one as one that was more obscure of sorts. It was a very good one to start with in my opinion. 
Story: It's more of a psychological story than I was used too. Every episode made me think about what was going on in my own life and I was easily able to relate. It deals with morality, the actions that people make, and how everyone must make their own choices. In the 24 episodes, the story is very wellplayed out. However, there are other series after xxxHolic that should be looked into if one wants to see the rest of the story played out. 


Art: It is a very different style than I'm used too. The art focuses on the main characters and the scenery, and those who aren't as important do not have as much detail. I like the contrast between the two. I'm not sure what to think of how people are portrayed in this series however. I have mixed feelings about how overly exaggerated the limbs on all the characters are. It is nothing to look down on though, the art is still very well done. 


Sound: There isn't much in the sense of different music in the series overall. The opening music though is quite catchy. 


Character: The characters are very well fleshed out. Not every character is seen in depth, but there is a good mix of those who are looked deep into and those who are covered, but not in an extreme amount of detail. The characters do have different relationships with one another, and the links are easy to follow. The cast is set up in a way that everyone can have a different favorite (in comparison to some who the majority of the people will be behind one specific character, normally the protagonist). 


Enjoyment: This is a very enjoyable anime. It's easy to follow, good character development, and each episode brings a message that people can take from it (minus a couple of episodes that seem to focus solely on entertainment, but there's no problem with that). Definitely a series that worth watching, be it once or a few times. 


Overall: Linear and straightforward story, good cast of characters, and it makes you think. I believe teens and young adults (say, late high school through college) kids may get the most out of it, being able to relate to the characters more.
